Award.AwardTitle: ETBC: Aerosol and Precipitation Chemistry and Deposition Rates in the Western Atlantic Trade Winds: The Link to Sources, Transport, and Deposition Processes - II
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will characterize aerosol concentrations and wet and dry deposition processes at Barbados and Miami, with foci on African dust and related constituents and on anthropogenic species. Observations will be based on a two-year daily sampling protocol on Barbados and at Miami supplemented by intensive field campaigns, including collaborative aircraft-based studies of aerosols and clouds by German scientists, to be carried out during various seasonal dust and pollution transport regimes. A major objective is to link results to larger-scale processes. To this end, on-site ground-based aerosol remote sensors (lidar and optical depth) will be used to link the surface-based measurements to the overlying atmosphere and also satellite products in order to generalize to larger scales.

The results will lead to a better understanding of the processes controlling the transport and deposition of African dust and associated substances over the tropical Atlantic and to improved estimates of the impact of deposition on marine biogeochemistry in this region. The integrated program (with remote sensing and modeling) will lead to a better characterization of large-scale dust transport/removal processes and a more quantitative modeling of them, including the linkage to source processes on an event-to-event basis. This, in turn, will lead to an improved understanding of the impact of atmospheric transport on biogeochemical processes in the global ocean and to the possible impact of climate change on dust mobilization and transport (and, hence, on ocean biogeochemistry and the carbon cycle). Also of concern is the possible role of anthropogenic materials transported to the ocean; these could directly affect biogeochemical processes in the ocean and, mixed with dust, the chemical properties of the dust, including the solubility of iron and other metals. A graduate student will be trained through participation in all aspects of the program. The Caribbean Institute for Meteorology and Hydrology will collaborate in the science activities and manage daily operations of the Barbados site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our program focuses on the study of aerosols, i.e., fine particles suspended in the atmosphere. Mineral dust is a major aerosol component in many regions of the world. In particular, the arid soils of North Africa are the world's largest dust source, accounting for as much of 70% of the global total. Each year hundreds of million tons of African dust are carried to the Western Atlantic and the Caribbean Basin and to the southern US where it affects our environment in a variety of ways. Dust alters the solar radiation balance and affects the properties of clouds and precipitation. Dust deposited to the ocean and land surfaces carries large quantities of phosphorous, nitrogen, and iron all of which are important nutrients for plants and marine organisms; thus dust deposition can have a great impact on carbon dioxide fluxes and on the Earth's carbon cycle which in turn can affect climate. But dust generation is itself a affected by climate change which can lead to complex feedbacks on climate.

 

The overall objective of our program is to understand the factors affecting aerosol properties and the impact of changing climate on dust transport to the Caribbean and the US. To this end we study changes in dust concentration and its physical and chemical properties on time scales ranging from hours to decades mostly based on long term measurements at Barbados (since 1965) and Miami (since 1974). We show that dust transport increased dramatically in the 1980s as a result of intense drought in African. Transport has decreased in recent decades apparently linked to increasing rainfall in the Sahel, a semi-arid region bordering the Sahara on the south. In a study using global chemical models and satellite images, we showed that land use in the Sahel has affected dust mobilization and that this source of dust will likely increase in the future as populations continue to grow in the region.

 

We have shown that dust deposition is a major contributor to soils on Caribbean islands, the Bahamas and Florida. Many of these locations have well-developed red soils despite the fact that they are located on coral platforms. Our measured deposition rates of African dust and its mineralogical composition is consistent with the formation of these soils. In a recent study in French Guiana, we showed that transport to South America is comparable to that carried to the Caribbean and the southern US. In another study using satellite products we show that African dust is carried to the Amazon Basin where it contributes significantly to soil nutrients.

 

In our current program we have made extensive measurements of the solubility of phosphorous and nitrogen compounds including unique studies of the role of organic species which we found to be an important component in our samples. The presence of organic species is significant in that they are expected to  be more readily utilized by organisms in the ocean and in soils. We have also characterized the solubility of iron in dust and its variability over the seasons. This is important to understanding how the input of dust and iron might affect the seasonality of productivity in the tropical Atlantic and, thus, the carbon cycle.

 

Aerosols are an important component in air quality, specifically particles in the size range under 10 µm diameter which can readily enter our respiratory system. We have shown that dust has a huge impact on air quality throughout our region. Because of dust, the World Health Organization air quality guidelines are exceeded at a high rate throughout the Caribbean Basin, rates comparable to those in urban areas of the US and Europe.
